description.narrative: Environment and Climate Change Component is one of the two components of NRE Programme developed to strengthen the capacity of REMA to secure effective pollution control for sustainable development, mainstream environment in different sector strategies, programmes and policies, and address climate change issues. The support will enhance human, institutional and technical capacities.

description.narrative: The expected and unexpected results achieved in the course of implimenting Environment and climate change component of the ENR Programme is summarized based on the objective of outcomes. The objective outcome 1 (Secure an effective environmental pollution control and management) is geared towards strengthening REMA's capacity to enable it to effectively monitor, regulate and control environmental pollution. The support also aims at strengthening the human capacity of REMA, and to some extent technical capacity in response to significant issues related to pollution. The support also include inputs in the form of short term technical assistance, on-the-job training, short term formal training for key identified staff (and support areas), technical inputs and equipment as well as engaging short term and hands on interactive training sessions for REMA staff with identified technical institutions abroad in the form of twinning arrangement.. The main activities implemented for this focus area include; procurement of equipment, direct capacity building through training, development of guidelines, reports, and enforcement of law on non-biodegradable plastic materials (hiring of a private company to implement the activity). A number of results were achieved by the programme including: several tools in the form of guidelines and assessment reports produced and disseminated to users and stakeholders. The vehicle emission monitoring tools in form of measuring equipments and a standard for Rwanda were shared with the relevant policing authority, skills training including the use of modern tools were provided to REMA, relevant police, environmental practitioners and industrial businesses, and other relevant stakeholders, and Data on pollution levels including daily vehicle emissions were collected. However, the database which was to be established and being the key tool for measuring the outcome of the programme intervention with respect to pollution control effectiveness was not established. This shortfall is assessed to be the weakness of the programme towards the attainmement of outcome objective 1. The results achieved under the objective outcome 2 (Strengthening Mainstreaming Capacity) include environment and climate change considerations effectively mainstreamed in district planning spearheaded mainly by the operational instruments and in particular the interns recruited and deployed by the programme as human capacity support to REMA staff. In terms of unexpected archieved results, the green village programme was unexpectedly achieved though it was not originally planned but is also assessed as positive results achieved. This was implemented to demonstrate adoption practices that support climate change resilience and as an activity for mainstreaming climate change resilience in policies, strategies and plans. It was noted that local governance institutions through district structures have adopted the green village approach for the implementation of the national rural resettlement programme. A set of positive results achieved under the objective outcome 3 (Strengthening Climate Change management capacity) include support to prepare national climate resilience instruments in a manner that have built REMA staff capacity in subject knowledge and skills and also enabled the institution to develop projects to leverage climate funds.The instruments were also made available to relevant stakeholders and practitioners for their use as appropriate. A number of results also achieved include developing four different guidelines and reports.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
